case_vignette: A 35-year-old man is brought to his psychiatrist by his wife. The patient’s wife says his last visit was 3 years ago for an episode of depression. At that time, he was prescribed fluoxetine, which he did not take because he believed that his symptoms would subside on their own. A few months later, his wife says that he suddenly came out of his feelings of ‘depression’ and began to be more excitable and show pressured speech. She observed that he slept very little but had a heightened interest in sexual activity. This lasted for a few weeks, and he went back to his depressed state. He has continued to experience feelings of sadness and shows a lack of concentration at work. She often finds him crying, and he also expresses feelings of guilt for all the wrongs he allegedly did to her and to the family. There was a week where he had a brief time of excitability and was considering donating all their savings to a local charity. She is highly perturbed by his behavior and often finds it hard to predict what his mood will be like next. The patient denies any suicidal or homicidal ideations. A urine toxicology screen is negative. All laboratory tests, including thyroid hormone levels, are normal.
question: Which  is the most appropriate diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling very sad, have trouble concentrating at work, I find myself crying often, and I'm dealing with feelings of guilt for things I think I've done wrong to my family.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I have been experiencing these symptoms for the past 3 years.
Have you noticed any changes in your sleep, appetite, or weight during this time?
My wife mentioned that I slept very little during periods when I was more excitable.
Have there been times when you've felt the opposite of sad, such as feeling extremely happy, overly talkative, or more active than usual?
Yes, there were a few weeks when I was much more excitable, talked a lot, and was very interested in sex, and there was another brief time when I wanted to donate all our savings to charity.
Do you have any personal or family history of mental illness?
The vignette doesn't provide information about any personal or family history of mental illness.
Have you been taking any medication for your symptoms or have you received any treatment for them in the past?
I was prescribed fluoxetine 3 years ago for an episode of depression, but I did not take it because I believed my symptoms would go away on their own.
Have you experienced any notable stressors or life changes around the time your symptoms started or before the periods where you felt extremely happy or excitable?
The vignette does not mention any specific stressors or life changes related to the onset of my symptoms.
**Final Diagnosis:** Bipolar disorder

I've been feeling really sad, have trouble focusing at work, and sometimes find myself crying for no clear reason.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been feeling this way on and off for the past three years.
Have there been periods during these three years when you've felt better? If so, how long do those periods typically last?
Yes, there were times when I suddenly felt much more excitable and had a lot of energy, but these periods only lasted for a few weeks.
During the times when you felt excitable and had a lot of energy, did you experience any decrease in the need for sleep or engage in any risky behaviors?

**Final Diagnosis:** Bipolar disorder
